column16: Mackay Regional Council staff altered monitoring techniques following continued presence of the croc in RWS2 pond during 2008/2009. Water quality is now assessed from a remote computer. column26: Racecourse Pond #2. Racecourse Ponds (3 in total) are Mackay Sugar effluent ponds which service surrounding cane farms. Mackay Regional Council has an effluent pond (RWS2) adjacent to Mackay Sugars ponds. Mackay Sugar and Mackay Regional Council effluent ponds are adjacent to Bakers Creek located approximately 5kms south of Mackay. I attempted to access site this morning however the Bakers Creek causeway was flooded. Mackay Sugar will notify me when flood waters reside.

column31: Public access not permitted at site. Mackay Sugar carries out water testing of the ponds when required. Workers predicted flood waters may result in the presence of a croc in the ponds. Croc was seen on Saturday by workers testing water.

column16: The coupling of today’s report with the partial report from a week ago provides sufficient confidence to investigate the report further. The size class is not indicative of a freshwater crocodile but the observation was made from a moving vehicle. Both freshwater crocodiles and estuarine crocodiles could potentially access the area during periods of heavy rainfall.
column26: Middle of the drain adjacent to Golf Links Drive near Elphinstone Drive, Kirwan

column34: An incomplete sighting was received from this area last week but contained very little veracity associated with the sighting and the caller hung up part way through the conversation. The new sighting requires site assessment to confirm presence / absence and to confirm species. Freshwater crocodiles are known from the upper reaches of the Bohle River (approximately 500m from the reported sighting). The lower reaches of the Bohle river have resident estuarine crocodile populations and it is not beyond the possibility of an animal moving upstream during recent flooding events. The area is highly populated and there are reports of local children using the drain for recreation.

column16: Crocs have been reported in the marina and along the breakwater wall previously and the sightings have been documented in the local media. Reported croc sizes have fluctuated. No 7m crocs have previously been reported to DERM staff in the Mackay/Whitsunday Region. I contacted Mackay Marina Yacht Club, SLSC lifeguard supervisor and VMR to report sighting. No other crocs have been reported to them. From the description given and the conditions at the moment there is a strong possibility that this was a large piece of floating debris and not a 20ft crocodile. I have attached images of the debris along harbour beach as a result of local flooding events. A recent sighting sign has been placed along the breakwater wall as a precaution.
column26: South of Mackay Marina breakwater wall
column34: Breakwater wall is popular fishing spot. SLSC patrolled beach located south of the breakwater wall was open today. Yellow caution flag was displayed in patrolled area due inclement weather, surf conditions and floating debris. People fishing were notified of reported sighting. No one was swimming when area was visited by DERM staff.
column46: Croc was reported to swim south from the breakwater wall and then turn in the direction of Flat Top Island (located approx 5km south-east of the Mackay Marina). Animal was seen to surface and submerge a number of times before slowly moving out towards Flat Top Island. Mackay is subject to spring tides and floods at the moment resulting in strong tidal flows and ocean currents.

column16: SLSC was contacted today, no crocs have been reported to or seen by the lifeguards. This is the second reported sighting this week. SLSC, VMR and Mackay Marina Yacht club were contacted yesterday in relation to the initial sighting and a recent sighting sign was deployed along the breakwater wall yesterday. The initial sighting was of a "20ft (initially 30ft) croc" which is a significant difference in size to this report. To date none of the animals reported have displayed aggressive behaviour and have been passing through. This appears to be the case in this instance; however as a precaution DERM staff will spotlight the area by vessel tonight to further assess the situation.

column16: The reported size class is sufficient to make the presence of an animal a potential threat. Not withstanding this the recommended controls are suitable to mitigate potential threat of the animal. The potential is prefaced on a lack of education with respect to the presence of crocodiles at the location. Removal would not alleviate the potential as no physical barrier exists to prevent another animal of any size class accessing the site. The recommended risk management approach is therefore exclusion of the human activity.

column16: The crocodile in question was observed circling the floats of a crab pot that had been placed in the water by QPWS staff, to observe its behaviour. It did not touch the floats at any time but did come close to them. The crocodile would then submerge and after a short time surface down stream. The animal approached the floats approximately 4 times and displayed the same behaviour. When the departmental crocodile vessel approached the animal it swiftly entered the water. We were only able to get to within 50mtr for photographs of the animal by drifting down stream on the current. Once again, when we got to close the crocodile, it entered the water swiftly and stayed submerged. When the pots were recovered it was noted that one of the bait packets which were secured to the bottom of the pot had gone missing and the end mesh had possibly been pushed in to gain access to the bait

column16: Croc was seen approximately 10km (by vessel) from the nearest public access point, however there is a small amount of public use at the site. The properties on the southern side of the creek do not have easy access to the water as there is a steep 20m embankment on the creeks edge. Residents on the northern side of the creek do have access to the waters edge and are aware of the crocs inhabiting the creek. A recent sighting sign has been placed at the Dunrock boat ramp to notify vessels that are heading up Sandy Creek. There is a report of a croc in Sandy Creek in today's (12/05/2010) Daily Mercury alerting public of the croc population in Sandy Creek. KD spoke to residents on both sides of the creek and was in the company of a resident when the croc was sighted. Residents are well aware of the crocs in the creek and observe them regularly. KD advised residents to contact DERM if the observe/have concerns about human/croc behaviour. This croc is a known croc to residents and did not exhibit aggressive behaviour, alternatively is appeared shy and moved away from human presence. This is not a croc of concern.

column16: The location is shared by multiple users and a variety of vessel sizes. It could be expected that the animals presence and display under normal circumstances would have elicited a response from the person to vacate the site. In this instance, the person is a commercial fisherman and was motivated to remain at the location to retrieve his harvest. I would not interpret the animal behaviour as an attack as the initial interaction was characteristic of a territorial display in crocodiles. The second interaction was not characteristic of an attack in that the animal did not lunge at the vessel or occupant with any speed nor did it inflict or attempt to inflict any bites to the vessel, outboard or person. The behaviour in the secondary interaction is more likely to have been motivated by the presence of food (fish) and an endeavour to recover the fish from the vessel. DERM has received 2 reports earlier this week regarding a 13-15 foot crocodile in Russell creek exhibiting behaviour indicating familiarity with vessels. The reports further allege that a commercial crab tour operator may be feeding the crocodile which in turn could be the source of the behaviour escalation in the animal. The Norman River is known crocodile habitat and historically spotlight survey has identified numerous large size class individuals. Without on site survey and assessment any desktop analysis resulting in an untargeted trapping regime has a high risk of capturing a non target animal. The reported sightings and combined Intel suggest a complex issue requiring measured assessment. If at some point trapping is required, a floating trap is based at the Maritime Safety compound in Karumba.

column16: The croc sighting is in an area that has a high amount of local boating/fishing traffic. The croc was reported to approach the boat "aggressively", however the action of the croc coming towards the boat may have been misinterpreted. The animal may have been trying to move out of sight from the vessel and the vessel was in its path. Without further verification of this report I do not recommend this animal is a croc of concern. The area will be monitored by DERM staff during surveys at similar times of the tide for the following week to assess the crocs behaviour.

column16: The size of the crocodile >2m inherently indicates a potential threat. Notwithstanding this desktop consideration, the animal was viewed briefly and exhibited normal crocodile behaviour in submerging following detection. Although Magnetic Island would not be considered high value crocodile habitat, island visitation by crocodiles is not uncommon and it is likely that the animal is seeking refuge in the bay while transient. The current weather forecast is 20-25knots winds and with substantial chop surrounding the island the bay may represent a safe refuge for the animal until weather subsides.

The Sheehan's were concerned about the use of the creek by the priest community and the possibility that people fishing off the weir would not be aware of croc presence. The site had been visited by DERM late 2008 however no further action was taken at that time. KD has placed a recent sighting sign at the weir and will erect a permanent warning sign on the road adjacent to the weir next week. KD visited the St Vincent De Paul community and urged them to act responsibly in croc country.

The Sheehan's were asked to continue to monitor the crocs behaviour and notify DERM in the event aggressive or unusual behaviour is observed. They were grateful of DERM's response.

The caravan park at Rose Bay has been contacted by myself advising them of the situation so they can advise their guests. Ranger Peter Sykes will put a steel frame in location tomorrow the 27.8.10 and he will do a daytime land based assessment of the area and will report through his findings. column16:
The size of the crocodile is unknown. 
About 5pm on Friday afternoon a person driving over the Isabella Creek bridge reported the dead cow to property owner Narelle. The head of the cow a leg and an udder have been ripped off.Cattle have free range on the property and access to Isabella Creek. No prevenation barriers are in place, as the cattle need to access the creek to drink from. 
Narelle also advised that their son needs to access an irrigation pump in the middle of the creek every few days to avoid blockage in the pump. Although he does this via boat, he still leans into the water to access the pump. It was advised that there are other ways for this to be done safely as this was not a safe way to be accessing the pump with known crocodiles in the area.

The property owners advised that QPWS officers have previously attended their property about 2 years ago following complaints about another crocodile, and that a trap was to be set, however nothing came of this. Narelle was not able to provide the name of the officers who visited or provided that advise.

Narelle would like the crocodile removed. Whilst no definate answer was given as to what will happen, I advised that even if the crocodile was removed that this would only be a temporary solution and that modifications to the drink access area would need to be considered to avoid future problems.
column26: Hazelmere Station - Isabella Creek.  Creek runs through Hazelmere Station and into the Endeavour River.
column34: Nearest road is the bridge crossing for Isabella Creek. Permanent crocodile signage is located at the crossing.
column46: Crocodile was not seen attacking, and the last time a crocodile has actually been physically sighted in the area was 2 years ago.

column16:
Construction work is currently taking place to upgrade the weir structure. This work is expected to run into mid-November.
The immediate section below the weir has been cordened off, and the water drained out from this area to undertake maintenance work and allow for vehicle and machine access. 
The crocodile was previously sighted outside of this sectioned area in the main river, but has climbed over the silt curtains into one the shallow ponds below the weir. Whilst there is a small possiblity that the crocodile could climb up the bank and out the area it still needs to access the main part of the river by moving through some more shallow ponds and rocky outcrops to be completely away from the construction area.
As construction work needs to continue it it is recommended the crocodile is removed and relocated into the main part of the river by appropriate QPWS staff

column32: Thorsborne Trail walkers cross this un-named creek at its mouth during their trek of the Thorsborne Trail. Crossing is undertaken at low tide and is usually undertaken acoss the beach on sand well clear of the creek proper. Water depth during crossing at low tide is usually less than 30 cms but can vary depending on tidal situation and current sand movement. This varies depending on tidal and weather conditions. Visibility across shallow sand prior to and during crossing is approximately 75 metres. About 30 persons (max) per day would cross the creek. It is most unlikely that there is any other use of this beach as it is remote (accessible by moderate sixed recreational vessel only) and provides no interest for other visitation.

column16: The report indicates an estuarine crocodile of up to 3m in length south of the known and accepted distribution of the species. The size class of the animal inherently represents a potential threat to human safety and although no behavioural triggers have been identified, the animal is reported from a habitat well south of its distribution and as such the human demographic is unlikely to expect the animal to be present. As such human behaviour in the area is unlikely to observe croc wise messages and the risk associated with interaction is thus elevated.

column16: The reported location is in close proximity to a popular boat ramp however, this is the only recent sighting report of an animal (to my knowledge) near the ramp.  As with most northern rivers with a stable population of crocodiles, the likelihood of a sighting occuring near public infrastucture is highly likely to occur throughout the year.  Therefore, consideration should be given to the animal's behaviour.  This animal showed no interest in remaining in its location when disturbed by the vessel.  At this stage there has not been any evidence of the animal exhibiting a desire to remain specifically in close proximity to the ramp.  It is more likely given the current overcast raining conditions the animal was taking advantage of a suitable basking area.

column46: The site was inspected where the crocodile was encountered. On arriving at the site, a large crocodile could be seen cruising upstream on the opposite side of the river (approx 120m away). The head and shoulders of the animal were clearly evident. The animal continued to cruise upstream before holding in the water about 150m from our position. We waved our arms, called out and clapped. The animal then slowly cruised across to our bank and proceeded down the northern bank until it was about 30m from our position. It then submerged and a number of bubble streams came up from directly below where we were standing.

column16: It appears the crocodile is inhabiting the drainage system some distance from the river. The average person would probably not expect to find a crocodile of this size in such a location as it would not be considered natural habitat, however most farmers in the area would aware crocodile inhabit these drains. In light of the animal being greater than 2.5m in length there is an inherent risk attached to the animal, however the animal is relatively isolated from local exposure to people and has not exhibited any behaviour of concern.
column26: In a drainage system on a cane farm in Lower Tully, the drain consists of a system of narrow channels and at least one larger settlement pond in the middle. The drain flows into the Hull River system. The property is in between the Hull and Tully rivers in a low area that is known to flood (not sure of flooding levels but cane paddock inundation has been observed and recorded). The location of this animal would be approx 1km from the river following the contiguous route of the drain. Most of the drain is only waist depth and clear water.
column29: Hull River is the nearest estuary by proximity and is the likely origin of the animal prior to moving into the cane drain on the Emmi property.
column30: The animal is reported and observed to be inhabiting a narrow drain and settlement pond constructed on farm land. There is limited vegetation cover to the drain and good basking sites are a available to the resident animal. There is known nesting which ha
column31: Given the land is privately owned, only the owners and contractors should have access to the area however it is reported that children do access the property on bicycles despite it being private land.
column32: There is potential that local children trespass on the property to access fishing locations. The use is otherwise rural/agricultural.
column34: The sugar cane on the property is currently being harvested. As the cane is harvested the drain and surrounding landscape becomes more exposed cane which may cause the site to be more visible and attractive to children.

Mr Perotta's has a shitzu, the dog was heard yelping on Friday night and hasn't been located since. While the dog may have been taken by a croc it can't be ruled out that it may have been taken by a wild dog. 

The dam is within Mackay Urban Management Area, however it is tidal and the croc has been reported during the peak of the tide. Due to increased rain events prior to Christmas and again in early February the croc may have been seeking refuge in the dam and has since moved back into Eimeo Creek.

Nothing can be concluded at this stage as the animal has not been seen since November 2010 and the dog may have been taken by a wild dog. It is not considered a croc of concern at this juncture however QPWS will carry out surveys and a further assessment will be provided with recommendations if the reported croc is seen in the dam.

Alva Beach - The observer was knee deep in the water surf fishing approx 1.8km from the old Northern carpark which accessed Alva Beach.
The animal is reported to have surfaced approximately 6-8m from the person fishing in open water. The animal didn't make any behavioural moves towards the fisherman (i.e. the observer has indicated to the reporter that he did not believe the animal to have a predatory intent) and it is reported that the fisherman was unaware of the animals presence initially. The water had considerable debris from the Burdekin river flooding and he noticed the animal in the water after fishing for a considerable time. The fisherman exited the water after noticing the animal and observed the animal for some time slowly moving along the beach for approximately 50m before he lost sight of it.

column16: Animal is within known crocodile habitat - The size of the animal inherently could be described as a potential threat.  Despite the inherent risk associated with any animal of this size class the animal is in well known crocodile habitat and existing controls in the form of signage are adequate to manage the presence of the animal.  The density in this particular river system predisposes the site to regular and proximal occurrence of c.porosus and the detection of a single animal without any behavioural cues to indicate the animal is 'of concern' should not pre-empt any management response beyond educational signage.

column16: The crocodile was first seen under a covered drain at Westcourt/Alfred Street. The animal then moved downstream for approx 100 m and stopped at the edge of the water on the northern side of the bank. The animal was facing the bank with most of its body exposed. It did not show any signs of aggressive behaviour. After 20 minutes the crocodile backed off into deeper water and swam submerged to the opposite bank which is covered in mangroves. Only its head was visible. 10 minutes later the animal turned and began to swim at speed. It was last seen heading downstream in deep water just before the covered drain on Mulgrave road. A foot survey down stream of this location failed to see the crocodile

column34:
The property ownerhas lived at the property since 2004 and this is the first time she has seen a crocodile.  The property is on the beach side of Snapper Island Drive and is located approximately 1 block from a small tidal inlet which is known as habitat for crocodiles. The houses in this area are built on natural tidal swales and lagoons and with the big wet there there has been plenty of localised flooding. To the northern boundary is another 50 metre lagoon. 
The dam on the property is located approximately ten metres from the back verandah of the house. The dam is estimated to be 50m x 70m. 
The owner owns two dogs and is concerned about their safety. Snapper Island Drive is within an urban residential area.

The likelihood of an attack occurring on a professional diver from a 2.0m crocodile is rare at best but the activity itself exposes the individual to potential attack from crocodiles of larger sizeclass as the Marina is not closed and offers no barriers to the access of crocodiles from the coast or the adjacent moon creek.
The person reporting the sighting did not report the issue direct to DERM but through the office of Local Member fro Barron River - Steve Wettenhall.
The person reporting the crocodile has been advised that a survey and assessment will occur in relation to the sighting and further advised to be croc wise in croc country and to exercise caution in relation to his chosen employment given the lack of barriers to crocodile movement into the Marina and the existing potential for animals of any sizeclass to occur at the location.

column16:
The crocodile was observed in an area where there is low general public use. Given location, it is believed the crocodile has been purposely released in the dam. The crocodile is not within natural habitat and is located within the Urban Management area for Townsville.

Allan has advised that, as of the 10th October 2011, the crocodile has been observed on several occaions in the past few weeks by staff in close proximity to nearby pathways and is not easily disturbed; however it should be noted that most of the path ways that run along the lagoon are on a steep bank, with an exception of a small section of the path.
Whilst defence has taken QPWS recent sighting signs to deploy at the site on base, they also have their own permanenet crocodile warning signs located near the lagoon.
column26: Lavarack Barracks - Upper dam/lagoon on Lavarack Barracks, Townsville. - The artificial water courses that run through the barracks are connected through man-made drains that eventually meet up with the Ross River. However, where the main water course meets defence land access is restricted by security grills. In addition to this the top dam/lagoon flows down into the bottom dam via a cememnt wall, only when the top dam is overflowing.
column31: Defence buildings. Access to this base is only by authorised personnel.
column32: The dam is not used for any other purpose on the base then for aesthetic value.

column16: The crocodiles have been obseved in an area above the causeway crossing the Bloomfield River at Wujal-Wujal. Because of the physical structure of the causeway, there is no barrier to prevent crocodiles moving into this area. It is common knowledge locally, that crocodiles inhabit the areas above and below the causeway.

Presence of the crocodile near the construction site could pose a risk to workers if appropriate risk management strategies are not implemented. Michael advised that some of his workers were concerned about the crocodile being in the area when they were undertaking work under the birdge. I advised Michael that he should look into some risk management strategies such as mush gates or netting of the immediate work area to try and exclude crocodiles from the work area. Abigroup should then make their own risk assessment for their workers from there.

column16:
The area the croc was reported is a high use area, however no aggressive behaviour was reported and the animal has not been reported since. QLD Police went to the site to try and locate the reported croc when they first received the information (17:30 - 31 Jan 2012). They did not observe any crocs. DERM visited the site again the following morning and no crocs were observed (1 Feb 2012).

The croc has not displayed any aggressive behaviour and appears to have moved on. It is not considered a croc of concern at this juncture.

column16: On the 21st Jan 2012, 2 x cross breed dogs went missing from a property on Hills Road , Edmonton. This property backs onto Wrights Creek, a documented crocodile habitat. Ms Rebecca Bond, the owner of the dogs recovered one animal that day, between 6.30-6.45pm, and noted that it had received several wounds to its body. A vet inspected the animal and said that the wounds were probably inflicted by another dog. The blue cattle x lab did not return. On the 26th Jan, Mr Tony Miles was setting his crab pots in Wrights Creek, down stream of Ms Bonds property when the remains of a black dog floated by. He was able to take a photo with his phone then informed Ms Bond of his find.

The kids in question have been alerted to the presence of crocs in the creek. The creek is currently in flood and is unlikely to be used for recreational purposes in the immediate future.

column16: The crocodile was observed when Raymond returned to the Derral boat ramp at 7.30pm last night . He had been fishing and was beaching his boat on the ramp. The crocodile surfaced behind the boat then submerged. It then reappeared to the side/rear of the boat then submerged again. The animal was last seen under a small cluster of trees to the right of the ramp. It did not leave the water at any time. This area of the Mulgrave River is a well documented crocodile habitat and there has also been several reports of fish offal being left on or near the ramp The crocodile did not display any aggressive behaviour and was not seen again.

column34: Walkers on the beach, often with dogs. Some people do cast netting. About 1.5 weeks ago, 3 young men were cast netting from the beach next to the jetty at 10pm, on a dark night. When asked if they were aware a crocodile was seen in this area, the reply was "yes" and they continued unconcerned. Other people, including indigenous people,  stand at the waters edge with fishing rods at the old Marine Parade boat ramp. Today at 11.30am I saw an indigenous woman and young (under ten?) girl cast netting on the beach next to the boat ramp. I went to talk to them. As I did so, an elderly man who was sitting in a chair on the beach with a fishing rod said they were his family. When I mentioned the crocodile had been seen here earlier at 9.30am, and also pointed out the warning signs, he said "yes" we know, were locals. The cast netting continued with the  comment we'll keep a look out for it. He also said 2 young men had been swimming a little south of the boat ramp earlier this morning (about 10am?). In addition there was an elderly man and possible grandson (about ten y.o) cast netting from the beach in front of the Rainforest and Reef Info Centre, just north of the jetty about 7-7.30am.

column16: The location may be perceived as a potential threat to public safety as it is not a natural waterway and is likely to be sub otimal habitat however the description of the drain indicates connectivity with a 'swamp' which may be suitable habitat. It is common for small animals such as this to move into these small drains and creeks as there is likely to be less disturbance. An animal of this size is unlikely to pose a direct threat to people.

column16: This creek does eventually connect to the Johnstone River, which is known crocodile habitat, and with the high amount of rain lately there is potential for crocodiles to move into areas they may not normally be seen. The water is a lot cooler up this part of the stream however the creek still has potential to be classed as crocodile habitat. The swimming hole of the park does connect onto Mena Creek, and Katherine has advised there are no barriers between the creek or the waterhole. Whilst the park does not actively promote swimming in the waterhole people do swim in it and there are no signs advising visitors to not swim. This waterhole is frequently used by visiting public to the park. The proximity of the crocodile to the park could be seen as a threat to human health and safety, however the the crocodile has not currently displayed any interest in the observors and Katherine advised that the park are not too worried about it.

column16:
There was a reported attack on a pig dog that works on the cane farm. Mr Sciberras did not personally witness the attack or the croc subject to the reported attack. The creek is known croc habitat and it is utlised by the locals in some sections of the creek.

A 5m croc was reported to DERM on the 28 March 2012 in a lagoon adjacent to Sandy Creek. Rangers did a day and night survey of the lagoon and no croc was observed. Mr Sciberras is aware of the recent sighting in the lagoon which prompted him to report this information.

Mr Sciberras was asked to talk to his farm workers and locals regarding this information and was given the hotline number to call for future sightings (he came into the QPWS office). Mr Sciberras did not think attempted removal of a croc would be affective, he knows of a number of crocs that live in the vicinty of his farm and is not confident he could identify the croc. He was concerned with regards to the permanenet sign removal at the causeway. 

While it is in close vicinity to the sighting before Easter, it cannot be confirmed that it is the same croc subject to both reports. The croc reported on the 28 March 2012 was 5m and the slide subject to this report is 70cm which would be that of an approximately 3.5m croc.

column16: Kim Heynen - A/Team Leader - There was an unconfirmed sighting at the Port of Airlie (away from main beach) on 09/11/12 which was reported on 12/11/12. Marine Parks deployed Recent Sighting Signs and the local council were contacted. Later that day the Royal Lifesaving Queensland club contacted EHP to discuss concerns in regards to the signage. The outcome of these discussion was that they would be available to assist EHP with any croc response (have a boat available in 10 mins) and they regularly patrol the beaches. Subsequent discussions were had with them today and they stated they have a boat spotlighting between 9pm and 10pm last night (they are keen to ensure no crocs within the vacinity of the beach as schoolies celebrations have begun today), they will do they same tonight and contact EHP tomorrow if they see anything.

column34: The person was the only one in the area, on the bank fishing, at the time he saw the crocodile. He first spotted it hooked up in a crab pot rope, right around the black float which was 50m out in the middle of the creek. (The person advised he was no more than 50-60m in triangle from where it was and could see fairly plainly.) The croc got out of the rope and proceeeded up Gavial Creek swimming on top of the water. The person left the area at 12.40pm and didn't see it again. It was his opinion that the croc would probably go up with the tide and back with the tide, as it's what they usually do. Graham is aware of the permanent crocodile warning sign near Gavial Creek Bridge; he didn't go that far this time, turned left before the sewerage plant on Quay Street. The next closest permanent warning signs are at the Quay St boat ramp and Quay St Gavial Creek Bridge

Additional comments:
Believe that Mr CONNOR has the knowledge and experience to recognise a crocodile in the wild. Mr CONNOR advised that he had worked in Cairns and North Queensland as a builder and has spent considerable time throughout the river systems up there, viewing crocs up there.

column30: system of little creeks, mangroves, isolated.
column34:
Creek was approx 20-30ft wide where Neil saw the animal. 
Neil was approx 30 metres from the animal when he saw it surface about 5 ft from bank. The animal travelled at 90 degree angle to the bank across the creek. Saw the animal swim in the direction of the opposite bank for approximately 5 seconds before the animal resubmerged. All he could see was the centre of the back. Animal moving fairly quickly, poss startled by the motor on the boat. 
Tide - was outgoing (just off high tide) at the time of the observation. Estimated that maybe 1/3 of the tide was out. Did not observe any slides or claw marks. Mangroves on either side of the creek. Neil advised that access to the creek requires high tide.
Neil advised that he could take officers to sighting location tomorrow (21/12/12) on the high tide which is in the middle of the day.

This crocodile was incidental capture and was at this location opportunistically feeding on fish. Nearby Thomatis Creek is confirmed crocodile habitat and not within the CUMA.
Dan Mead- Further investigation has identifed this facility has a perimeter fence which is likely to sevre as an adequate prevention barrier. While obviosuly there are some faults (a crocodile has passed through it) it appears to at least deter animals from entering the facility. The landholder reports only one other animal has entered the facility in the last 5 years. Saff did not inspect this fence while on site to assess its suitablity as a prevention barrier but subsequent conversations with the Landholder indicate the struction is in reasonable condition.

A dog is an accepted potential food source for a crocodile, the behaviour that was reported that the animal approached the dog is expected croc behaviour. The animal submerged and didn't resurface after John made it aware of his presence by standing up.

column16: Animal has been sighted in boat ramp area on three consecutive nights 25,26,27/02/14 arriving at approximately 2100hrs. Reporting person was fishing off the bank on the 25th and sighted the animal by torch light. on the 26th the reporting person was fishing from a vessel close to the bank opposite the boat ramp with floats. Reporting person was sitting in the dark. he then turned a torch on to check his fishing lines and sighted the animal sitting stationary within reaching distance from the front of his vessel. once the torch light hit the animal it submerged, only to resurface moments later in the same vicinity. the reporting person attempted to deter the animal by poking it with the tip of his fishing rod. the animal submerged and resurfaced in the same vicinity. the person then fended the animal with his oar. the animal submerged once more and appeared a few metres away. the animal then proceeded to attack the fishing floats as well as try to eat a fish the reporting person had caught on a line and was reeling in. the reporting person sighted the animal in the same location at the same time on the following night

column16: This crocodile may be a potential threat given its size and proximity to the staff at the prawn farm and due to its ability to conceal itself in the ponds that staff are required to enter to carry out their daily duties. The crocodile is within zone 3 of the Hichinbrook Shire Council's crocodile management area. The crocodile is approximately 3.5m in length. The animal currently resides within the farm boundaries, however the farm lies embedded in some of Queensland's most well known crocodile habitat the Hichinbrook channel, an area of extensive mangrove channels between Hichinbrook Island and the Queensland coast with a healthy crocodile population. No barriers currently exist to prevent crocodiles entering the farm from the surrounding mangrove area.

column34: The persons reported the sighting after her children had seen the crocodile when they went down to the creek for a swim. She mentioned that children often go swimming in the creek. The creek is approximately 3 meters wide and no deeper than 1 meter where the sighting took place, although Mrs Evens believes it increases in size considerably after heavy rainfall. I would consider where the sighting occurred in Giddens Creek to be sub optimal crocodile habitat but it does flow into Babinda Creek which is known crocodile habitat.

column16: Crocodile is located south of the Boyne River.
column26: Pontoon, Lamington Bridge Boat Ramp, Mary River, Maryborough
column34:
The person works at Mary River Marine Supplies. He had two youth (approx 15 years) come into the store today asking what they were likely to catch in the Mary River. The person  advised they might catch bull sharks or catfish, to which the kids responded 'we haven't caught either of them but we caught a baby crocodile on the fishing line at the end of the pontoon at the Lamington Bridge Boat Ramp'. The animal was approximately the the length of their forearm (~30 cm)'. The kids advised that they didn't know what to do with it so they threw it back into the water.
Chris advised that given the size of the croc, if there was a female croc nesting in that particular area there was a gully called Ululah Creek which runs behind the Caravan Park located on Hyne Street which was inaccessable to boats. The entrance of this creek onto the Mary River is immediately upstream of the Lamington Bridge at coordinates -25.523911, 152.687791.
Chris did not obtain a contact number for the kids. He thought about that after they had left the store.

column16: Crocodile is located south of the Boyne River
column26: Maryborough Public Wharf
column34:
Chris works at Mary River Marine Supplies. 
Advised that he had been told by Ted, one of his regular customers (and friend) about an incident that involved one of Chris's other good friends in the period between 24 Dec and 3 Jan.
Chris's friend was loading cartons of bottled water into his boat at the Maryborough Public Wharf. The man noticed that a log had been sitting next to the boat throughout the duration of this activity and had not moved. Thinking this was unusal the man moved closer to inspect the log. Upon approach the log raised to the surface and opened its eyes. 
The man jumped backwards and launched himself into the boat.

column16: The smaller of the 2 crocodiles was seen in the proximity of the mouth of Eli Creek and surfaced behind a lure which the witness had cast towards the mangroves, this crocodile had then sumbmerged and the witness watched the buble trail heading towards his kayak before he paddle away. The bigger of the 2 specimens is was witnessed approx 150m away from a housing estate near a drain that forks off into 2 channels,  this drain then runs up behind a housing estate - we have had no sightings of crocodiles in this area before. 2 staff have conducted a vessel patrol of the area and no sightings or evidence was found.
column26: Mouth of Eli Creek, Hervey Bay 250 meters north - two locations -25.25710, -25.25932  152.80786, 152.80642

column46: One of the crocdiles submerged facing the witness about 20 metres away and made it's way towards the witness, the second crocodile submerged and swam away in the opposite direction.

column16: The crocodile is not located in natural habitat, and is in area that presents a health and safety risk to staff undertaking water quality testing
column26: Moa Island
column34:
The crocodile is located in a sewerage pond approxiamnetly 2km out of town.
The facility contains 5 ponds, 50m x 50m, surrounded by a chain mesh fence. The ponds are about 2.5m deep in the middle, and are lined with plastic. There is once main pond that is used to pump sewerage waste into; all other ponds are used as overflow ponds. 
There is no food source available in the ponds. It is believed the crocodile moves between each pond, and due to the murky water it is difficult to locate in which pond the crocodile is. 
Staff need to undertake water quality testing once a month, as well as occasional mowing of the lawn surrounding the ponds. The presence of the crocodile in the ponds presents a health and safety issue for those staff undertaking water testing once a month. Currently 2 staff undertake the water sampling for OHS reasons.
The location cannot be located on google earth, so a map has been requested from the Manager of the facility to gauge the layout of the area, and locate nearyby water courses.

I recommend that this animal is moving through the location

The crocodile was reported to have put its head over the bow and one of the occupants struck it on the head with an oar, removing a flap of skin between its eyes.

The men left the area, then concerned about public safety returned to see if the animal was still about. Upon the men returning to the location, the crocodile was reported to again present beside the boat.

column34: The personis a local commercial fisherman who has seen many resident crocodiles in the Boundary Creek area. On this particular day he was out fishing and seen the crocodile laying on the banks near the mouth of Boundary Creek. At the time it was raining quiet heavily and the person’s boat was filling with water, he had a fishing net in the water and had to leave it to go back to a bank away from the area so he could empty his boat as he did not want to enter the water where the crocodile was. Fisheries witnessed the person leaving his net in the water and subsequently followed him back. During conversation with Fisheries the person explained the situation that the crocodile was in the area that he therefore had to leave his net in the water so he could empty his boat. As a subsequent of this conversation Fisheries contacted EHP to advise of their conversation

column34: The person was the only person in the area, in a tinny trolling for barramundi at the time he saw the crocodile. It was bottom of low tide and Dennis said the croc was 2m, maybe more. The person was in the area for an hour (4-5pm) and the croc was there the whole time, at first sunning it self on the bank and then swimming around (in the same bank area). The person said it didn't seem concerned about him being there, and he himself wasn't concerned about the croc.  The person said there had been some pro boats in the area so it could have been cleaning up fish. He also observed it was likely it could have been in the area due to recent flooding. The person had rung to report it today as he didn't know if anyone else had reported it. I advised no other reports and it was well known croc habitat, which Dennis confirmed he knew. The person also confirmed closest boat ramp was the new Quay St boat ramp and he was aware of the permanent croc warning signs throughout that general area.

column34:
Sighting reported by QPS Officer John Tantalo from Halifax Police. A member of the public reported to QPS driving along Farnell Drive last night and having to swerve around the head of large crocodile as the animal was lying near the edge of the road with its head on the road surface. The man reported that it was a very large head. The incident was reported to QPS as a near miss as it had the potential to cause a motor vehicle accident.
QPS visited the site and installed two EHP recent crocodile sighting signs on wooden pickets at the location that had been previously provided to them by staff. The officers conducted a spotlight search from the banks of the wetland on both sides of the road and in a short time observed two crocodile eyeshines on one side of the road (estimated 1.5 and 2.5m crocodile)  and one noticeably brighter/larger eyeshine on the other side of the road (estimated 3.0m+).  
There is a permanent crocoidle warning sign at this location and the area is known crocodile habitat.
Officer John advised that locals and visitors walk along the edge of the wetland and he has previously seen people picking the lily flowers from the water's edge.

column16:
The location of a crocodile in any area is a potential threat to human health and safety should proper caution not be exercised.
It is common for many locals to swim at the mouth of the creek, despite warnings from DEHP officers in the past.  
Opportunities to place permanent warning signs at the mouth of the creek have previously been explored, however the adjacent caravan park has expressed concerns that the sign would ‘scare off tourists’.
This creek has historically had sighting reports and is known crocodile habitat, however it is unlikely for a crocodile to permanently reside in the creek, as the food sources are limited. It is most likely the crocodile was opportunistically in the creek whilst moving between two major river systems (Bohle and Ross River), or became stuck in the creek at low tide and could not move back into Cleveland Bay.

column34:
The person set a couple of crab pots in the creek earlier that day. Wayne heard a noise and suspected it to be a crocodile therefore came back later in the evening to have look with a torch. It was at this time he observed red eye shine and determined it was a crocodile. The person did not see any other part of the body. The person gave an estimate of the crocodiles size based on the distance between eyes, however I explained to the person that this cannot be used as a judge on animal size.
The crocodile was observed about 10-15 away from Wayne, and was located at the Evans Street bridge (Belgian Gardens), next to the Rowes Bay cemetery.

column16: The croc sighting was confirmed at 2.30pm 15/08/013 sunning on the bank at the precise location described. It appears to be habituated to cars and trucks, but very wary of people. Upon seeing us out of the car (and with Mr Titmus the day before) it slid into the water and observed from the middle of the lagoon. We stayed for 20min and it barely moved. The croc is obviously 'minding its own business' quietly by a lagoon with a plethora of native food.The croc would be a post flood resident.

column16:
A crocodile in any location can present a risk to human health and safety should appropriate croc wise not be behavior be exercised.
Marty has advised that the creek is used for various activties including pumping water, cattle crossing, and a place to swim during the warmer months. 
Marty also has concerns that other crocodiles may be in the area, despite no evidence of this. Marty has made this suggestion based on a few young cattle going missing, and the presence of other predators in the area being low (mainly dingoes due to trapping programs). 
Whilst there are no known physical barriers in place to stop crocodiles from moving into the area, the surrounding landscape could provide some natural barriers. Not withstanding this, the area could be a major flood plain with potential for animals to move into areas during high floods.
The property has been in Martys family for approx 100 years, and crocodiles have never been known in the area, however Freshwater crocodiles are known to occur around Mount Suprise.

column26: Half tide boat ramp, Ramp Road, St Helens Beach QLD 4798
column34:
12-13 kids  were playing/swimming/throwing cast nets at the St Helens Boat Ramp at low tide. At the time of the incident no adults were present. 
Gary advised that he had been down with the kids, went up the top of the ramp where they were camping and upon return all of the kids were out of the water and looking a bit pale. Gary's son James (13) advised that they had seen ripples in the water at which a crocodile surfaced and moved approximately 20 metres from shore. The kids saw the animals head and exited the water. 
Gary asked his son what he saw. James said that all they saw was the head of the crocodile which was as big as the head that he had seen with his father when they were fishing in the Proserpine River. Gary advised that that particular animal was approximatley 3 metres in length. 
Gary doesn't believe that the animal was behaving agressively but drawn to the boat ramp due to the activity on the edge of the water by the kids playing in the water in combination with the use of cast nets by two of the kids.

column16:
A crocodile in any location can present a health and safety risk, should people not exercise croc wise behaviour.
Conrad advised that children use the main beach front for swimming and that, particularly with the school holidays, many children are swimming at the beach. Crocodiles are known in the area, but the presence of such a large crocodile along the main beach front that continues to hang around is starting to cause concern in the local community.
In addition to this, with reports that locals may try and trap the crocodile themselves, this may present further health and safety risks both to those persons attempting to catch the crocodile or people using the area for water based activities.
